title: Exception Basics
description: Learn about exceptions and error handling in Python.

cards.front: What is an exception in Python?
cards.back: An exception is an error that occurs during program execution. When an exception occurs, the normal flow of the program is disrupted.

cards.front: What is the purpose of try-except blocks?
cards.back: Try-except blocks allow you to handle exceptions gracefully. Code that might raise an exception goes in the try block, and error handling code goes in the except block.

cards.front: What happens if an exception is not handled?
cards.back: If an exception is not caught, the program terminates and displays a traceback showing where the error occurred.

cards.front: What is the finally block used for?
cards.back: The finally block contains code that will always execute, regardless of whether an exception occurred or not. It's often used for cleanup operations.

cards.front: What is the difference between SyntaxError and ValueError?
cards.back: SyntaxError occurs when Python can't parse the code. ValueError occurs when an operation receives a value of the right type but inappropriate value.

cards.front: What is the else block in try-except?
cards.back: The else block executes only if no exception occurred in the try block.

cards.front: How do you catch multiple exceptions?
cards.back: except (TypeError, ValueError) as e: or separate except blocks.

title: Common Exceptions
description: Familiarize yourself with frequently encountered exceptions.

cards.back: NameError occurs when you try to use a variable or function name that hasn't been defined.
TypeError occurs when an operation is applied to an object of inappropriate type, like trying to add a string and an integer.
IndexError occurs when you try to access an index that doesn't exist in a sequence, like accessing list[10] when the list only has 5 elements.
KeyError occurs when you try to access a dictionary key that doesn't exist.
ZeroDivisionError occurs when you try to divide a number by zero.
AttributeError occurs when you try to access an attribute that doesn't exist on an object.
ValueError occurs when an operation receives a correct type but inappropriate value, like int('abc').
ImportError occurs when an import statement fails to find the module.
FileNotFoundError occurs when trying to open a file that doesn't exist.
PermissionError occurs when trying to perform an operation without sufficient permissions.
OSError occurs for system-related errors like file operations failing.
RuntimeError occurs when an error is detected that doesn't fit other categories.
StopIteration is raised by iterators when there are no more items.
KeyboardInterrupt occurs when user presses Ctrl+C to interrupt program.
SystemExit is raised by sys.exit() to terminate the program.
